section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter establishes standards for the provision of dry needling as an intervention performed by chiropractors.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Board” means the State Board of Chiropractic Examiners.
“Dry needling” means a chiropractic intervention, also known as intramuscular manual therapy, that:
Is performed only by chiropractors with physical therapy privileges;
Involves the insertion of one or more solid needles, a mechanical device, into the muscle and related tissues to affect change in muscle and related tissues;
Requires ongoing evaluation, assessment, and re-evaluation of the impairments;
Is only utilized in parts of the body with neuromuscular or musculoskeletal links to the impairments; and
Is not performed for:
The purposes of acupuncture as defined in Health Occupations Article, §1A-101, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Any purpose outside the scope of chiropractic.
A chiropractor registered to perform dry needling shall:
Fully explain dry needling to the patient in advance of treatment;
Obtain informed written consent specific to dry needling, which shall be included in the patient’s medical record;
Perform dry needling in a competent manner consistent with patient health and safety; and
Document the provision and the specific location of the dry needling service in accordance with the requirements of COMAR 10.43.14.03.
A chiropractor who performs dry needling in a manner inconsistent with the standards of practice enumerated in this regulation may be subject to discipline pursuant to COMAR 10.43.15.06.
Dry needling is not within the scope of practice for:
A registered chiropractic assistant;
A chiropractic assistant trainee;
A preceptor; or
An extern.
A chiropractor with physical therapy privileges shall be in good standing before registering to perform dry needling.
The Board shall accept a dry needling course completed before May 18, 2020, if:
The same course, in substantially similar form, is sponsored by a continuing education provider approved by the Board; and
The chiropractor seeking to perform dry needling provides the Board with a certificate of completion of 3 hours of a recertification course in dry needling.
In order to perform dry needling, a chiropractor with physical therapy privileges shall complete a minimum of 80 hours of total instruction in the following content areas, including:
60 hours of:

Academic coursework obtained through completion of a college program accredited by the Council of Chiropractic Education, as part of the Doctor of Chiropractic program, including the following minimum requirements:
Foundations;
Basic sciences;
Clinical sciences; and
Professional practice; or
Coursework required to sit for Part I, Part II, Part III, Physiotherapy, and Part IV of the examination administered by the National Board of Chiropractic Examiners; and
Board-approved coursework consisting of 20 hours to be done in a hands-on classroom setting, including but not limited to the following learning topics:
Philosophy and historical perspective of dry needling;
Indications, contra-indications, and qualifications for treatment;
Protocols, doctor and patient safety, usage of dry needling, and dry needling as a diagnostic tool;
Case management and jurisprudence; and
Direct, hands-on implementation and testing for competency in dry needling of:
Cervical, thoracic, lumbar, and pelvic regions;
Anterior and posterior thoracic and ribs;
The upper and lower extremity;
The face and head;
Technique; and
Needle size and gauge appropriateness.
The Board shall register a chiropractor with physical therapy privileges as qualified to perform dry needling in the State, provided the chiropractor submits to the Board:
Evidence of completion of the education and training requirements outlined in Regulation .04 of this chapter; and
An application for registration on a form provided by the Board.
A chiropractor with physical therapy privileges may not perform dry needling without registering with the Board.
